feed.title: NewsTracker: germanwings

entry.title: Remains of some Germanwings crash victims being sent home
entry.summary: Germanwings' parent company Lufthansa has chartered a plane to bring the coffins to Germany, and has said that other remains will be repatriated by month's end.

entry.title: Remains of Germanwings crash victims head home
entry.summary: Germanwings' parent Lufthansa has said other remains will be repatriated by month's end.

entry.title: 11 weeks after Germanwings crash, victims' remains head home
Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary:
An examination of the baggage and the aircraft itself yielded no results, Germanwings said in a separate statement later on Sunday evening.

Germanwings said passengers would be able to fly to Milan on a different aircraft on Sunday night while the searched plane has been cleared for air traffic.

Lufthansa has faced questions about its pilot screening process since the March 24 Germanwings crash which appears to have been caused by a co-pilot who suffered from depression and deliberately steered the plane into a mountain.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: victims' remains airlifted from remote Alps site
entry.summary: Seyne-les-Alpes: Helicopters have begun airlifting the remains of the victims of the Germanwings plane crash from the disaster site in the French Alps.

entry.title: Return of Germanwings victims' remains delayed
entry.summary: A Germanwings spokesman said the delay -- which also affects the repatriation of victims from other countries -- was caused by errors in the official death certificates that had rendered them invalid.

entry.title: Spanish royals in Paris for visit; will honor crash workers
entry.summary: Felipe will also give a special award to emergency officials who cleared the wreckage of a Germanwings plane that crashed March 24 in the French Alps en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

entry.title: Investigators: Germanwings co-pilot practiced descent before crash
entry.summary: The revelation about the earlier flight that day from Duesseldorf to Barcelona appeared to support the theory that the Germanwings crash was not only deliberate but premeditated.

entry.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Tested Descents Hours Before Crash
Germanwings pilot rehearsed crash on outbound flight
entry.summary:
As the jet steadily lost height, Marseille air traffic controllers tried 11 times to contact the Germanwings jet.

However, it said the aeromedical centre of Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, twice refused to renew his medical certificate in 2009 when he was undergoing treatment for depression.

It promised also to look at where to draw the line between the need to prevent possible attacks by passengers and the need to prevent a repeat of incidents such as the Germanwings crash.

entry.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Tried Slow Descent Before
entry.summary:
Germanwings' parent company Lufthansa technically could have known about Lubitz' apparent rehearsal on the outbound flight, but only if it had looked at the flight data in the short period while the plane was unloading and loading passengers in Barcelona.

Germanwings said it "welcomed any new information that can help clarify what happened" but said it would not comment on the BEA report because of the ongoing investigation.

entry.title: Germanwings pilot rehearsed for crash on previous flight: Investigators
entry.summary: PARIS - The Germanwings co-pilot suspected of deliberately crashing a jet in the Alps in March practiced entering the fatal descent settings on the previous, outbound flight, investigators said.

entry.title: Germanwings plane disaster: co-pilot may have practised descent
Germanwings co-pilot practiced before crashing plane: report
entry.summary: Lufthansa, which owns Germanwings, declined to comment on the Bild report, pointing to the ongoing investigation.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot practiced descent on outbound flight before crash: report
Germanwings pilot was briefly refused medical certificate in U.S.
entry.summary: But it has said that Lufthansa, which owns Germanwings, had followed correct procedures under rules that applied at the time.

entry.title: Germanwings pilot was briefly refused medical certificate in U.S.
FAA had questioned mental health of Germanwings pilot
Germanwings crash families could seek damages in the US, lawyer says
entry.summary: Almost half of the victims of the Germanwings Barcelona to Duesseldorf flight were German, with the remaining passengers hailing from a range of countries including Australia, Spain and Argentina.

entry.title: Germanwings crash families could seek damages in the U.S.: lawyer
entry.summary: FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Families of the victims of the Germanwings crash are considering filing a claim for damages in the United States if they cannot reach agreement with parent airline Lufthansa in Germany, a lawyer representing the families said on Sunday.

entry.title: Germanwings crash victims remembered
entry.summary: COLOGNE, Germany - The passengers and crew killed in the Germanwings plane that crashed into the French Alps were remembered on Friday at a memorial service in which 150 candles were lit on the steps of the altar of Cologne Cathedral.

entry.title: Germanwings crash victims remembered with candles and angels
entry.summary: Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, cancelled its 60th anniversary celebrations set for April following the disaster and set up screens showing live coverage of the memorial service at its main bases.

entry.title: German president: Germanwings crash an 'unbelievable horror'
Relatives, dignitaries remember Germanwings crash victims
Relatives, dignitaries remember Germanwings crash victims
entry.summary: A mourning ceremony is held in the Cathedral in memory of the 150 victims of the Germanwings plane crash last month in the French Alps.

entry.title: After Alps crash, Turkish Airlines CEO wants pilots to wed
entry.summary: ISTANBUL (AP) - Turkish Airlines' CEO says that pilots may not be as prone to destructive behavior like that of the Germanwings pilot believed to have intentionally crashed a flight last month - if only they get married.

entry.title: Relatives, dignitaries pay tribute to Germanwings crash victims
entry.summary: "We really don't know what was going through his head during those deciding seconds, in the deciding minutes," Gauck told the congregation that also included Chancellor Angela Merkel, ministers from Spain and France, and the heads of Germanwings and its parent airline, Lufthansa.

entry.title: Following Germanwings crash, aviation safety experts weigh ground functions to override pilots
entry.summary: But following the intentional crashing of Germanwings Flight 9525 by the co-pilot, a long-running debate over autonomous jets is resurfacing.

entry.title: Germanwings crash could prompt remote override tech review
Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: Germanwings said the pilot of Flight 4U 826 to Milan was taxiing to the runway when he received a call from the air traffic tower at Cologne/Bonn airport to abort the flight.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after bomb scare
entry.summary: BERLIN (Reuters) - A Germanwings flight bound for Italy from Germany was evacuated late on Sunday due to a bomb threat, the airline said.

entry.title: Germanwings Plane Evacuated After Bomb Threat Received
entry.summary:
The tower in Cologne alerted the pilot of the Airbus A320, which was taxiing toward the runway at the time, Germanwings said.

Germanwings planned to fly the passengers to Milan on another plane.

entry.title: Germanwings plane evacuated after police receive bomb threat
entry.summary: BERLIN (AP) - Germanwings says a plane headed for Milan was evacuated at Cologne-Bonn airport after German police received a bomb threat against the flight.

entry.title: Woman pretended to be Germanwings crash relative to get free flights: Reports
entry.summary: A woman allegedly pretended to be a cousin of a Germanwings crash victim to get free flights to the French Alps, according to German media reports.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: 'Fake relative' claims free flights to French Alps
Germanwings co-pilot may have spiked pilot's drink with diuretic, report says
Police probe if woman faked link to crash victim for flights
entry.summary: BERLIN (AP) - German police are looking into whether a woman claimed to be a relative of a victim of last month's Germanwings crash to get free flights to southern France.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: FILE - In this March 26, 2015 file photo, rescue workers work at debris of the Germanwings jet at the crash site near Seyne-les-Alpes, France.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: "The circumstances of the investigation of the Germanwings accident have been highly unusual, and something that began as an accident investigation morphed into a highly public criminal investigation in which it seemed that every day new revelations were coming out," Tyler said.

entry.title: Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
entry.summary: The subsequent investigation has focused in large part on the pilot's history of depression and procedures at Germanwings and its parent company, Lufthansa, for screening pilots for mental health issues.

entry.title: Airline industry official expresses concern about the handling of Germanwings investigation
Airline official: Germanwings probe shouldn't set precedent
EU was looking into airline safety regulations prior to Germanwings crash in the French Alps
entry.summary: BRUSSELS - European Union authorities were looking into German airline safety procedures on "a number of issues" well ahead of the March 24 Germanwings crash after a standard inspection by its aviation safety agency questioned some procedures.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Lufthansa defends not reporting depression
entry.summary: German aviation industry doctors say that pilots should undergo more extensive medical checks in the wake of the Germanwings crash in the French Alps that killed 150 people.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: Aviation watchdog unaware of co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical history
entry.summary: Berlin: The German aviation authority did not know about co-pilot Andreas Lubitz's medical background prior to the Germanwings crash that killed 150 people, raising more questions over medical oversight of pilots.

entry.title: EU agency noted 'non-conformity? with Germany's air safety rules before Germanwings crash
Lufthansa CEO Spohr treading cautiously after Germanwings crash
entry.summary:
Still ahead is the April 17 memorial service in the massive cathedral in Cologne, near where Germanwings is headquartered.

The disaster during the flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf has subjected the airline to scrutiny over whether Lubitz should have been allowed to join its budget subsidiary Germanwings in 2013.

entry.title: France halts search for bodies at Germanwings crash site
Germanwings plane diverted to Stuttgart due to suspected oil loss
Germanwings plane diverted to Stuttgart due to suspected oil loss
entry.summary:
FRANKFURT (Reuters) - A Germanwings flight to Venice was diverted to Stuttgart on Saturday as the Airbus A319 aircraft appeared to be losing oil, the airline said in a statement.

Germanwings flight 4U814, with 123 passengers and five crew members on board, took off from Cologne at 9.55 a.m. local time (0355 EDT).

Germanwings said the pilots shut off one of the aircraft's engines and headed for Stuttgart when the problem was detected.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot increased speed as jet went down
Germanwings co-pilot accelerated descent, French investigators reveal
entry.summary: PARIS -- The co-pilot of the doomed Germanwings flight repeatedly sped up the plane as he used the automatic pilot to descend the A320 into the Alps, the French air accident investigation agency said Friday.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had researched suicide and cockpit doors: prosecutors
Investigators Find Body Parts From All 150 Germanwings Victims
Second Germanwings crash black box found
entry.summary: PARIS - The second 'black box' data recorder from the site of last week's Germanwings plane crash has been found, France's Gendarmerie police authority said on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot lied to doctors about sick leave: report
entry.summary: Although Lubitz gave doctors information about his job as a pilot, and in some cases about his employer Germanwings, he deliberately concealed the fact that he was still working, the paper said.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot lied to doctors about sick leave -Bild
entry.summary: Germanwings parent Lufthansa said on Tuesday that when Lubitz resumed pilot training in 2009 he provided the flight school with medical documents showing he had gone through a "previous episode of severe depression".

entry.title: LUFTHANSA KNEW: Airline admits co-pilot reported depression in 2009 - VIDEO: Lufthansa admits it knew of co-pilot's 'depressive episode' - French Alps crash shows psychiatrists cannot be last line of defense
entry.summary: The Germanwings crash has already produced some changes in aviation procedures.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: passenger video 'found'
entry.summary: London: A video of the last moments on the doomed Germanwings plane has been found on a mobile phone memory card at the crash site in the French Alps, according to reports.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz admitted depression
entry.summary: Lufthansa which owns Germanwings, said 27-year-old Andreas Lubitz had told the company in 2009 about his illness after interrupting his flight training.

entry.title: Germanwings Pilot Told Lufthansa of His Depression in 2009
Lufthansa: Co-pilot told flight school of depressive episode
entry.summary: The revelation that officials Lufthansa had been informed of Lubitz's psychological problems raises further questions about why he was allowed to become a pilot for its subsidiary, Germanwings, in September 2013.

entry.title: Psychological profiling, doors focus of French Germanwings probe
Psychological profiling, doors focus of French investigation [Photos] [Video]
entry.summary: BERLIN/PARIS - French air accident authority BEA said its probe into the Germanwings crash would study "systemic weaknesses" that might have led to the disaster, such as psychological profiling and cockpit door locks.

entry.title: French eye cockpit entry, psychological screening rules
entry.summary: Lufthansa - Germanwings' parent company - offered immediate aid last week of up to 50,000 euros ($54,250) per passenger to relatives of the victims.

entry.title: France eyes cockpit entry, psychological screening rules after Germanwings crash
entry.summary:
BEA said it aims to provide a "detailed analysis" of the Germanwings cockpit voice recorder and any other flight data - but it also plans to widen its search to examine issues that could be problematic for all airlines.

Several airlines and the European aviation regulator have already changed procedures after the Germanwings crash, announcing last week that they now recommend having two people in the cockpit at all times.

entry.title: Lufthansa insurers to set aside $300 million for Germanwings crash
Families of victims of Germanwings plane crash could face up to four months waiting for loved ones remains to be identified?
entry.summary: The families of victims of the Germanwings plane crash face a wait of up to four months for the remains of their loved ones to be identified, it has emerged.

entry.title: Lufthansa CEO faces tough test after Germanwings crash
entry.summary: "It was a big step to use Germanwings for European short-haul flights outside of Frankfurt and Munich and that commercial side of the business has to continue," he said.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: 'The pain is almost unbearable': grieving Australian family visit the crash site
entry.summary: Melbourne Germanwings plan crash victims Carol Friday and son Greig Friday.

entry.title: Prosecutors: Germanwings co-pilot was treated for suicidal tendencies
entry.summary: The co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525 that crashed into the French Alps last week had received treatment for suicidal tendencies several years ago, prosecutors said Monday.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot treated for suicidal tendencies years ago - prosecutors
Australia orders cockpit 'rule of two' after Germanwings crash
Australia, after Germanwings disaster, mandates at least two people stay in cockpits
entry.summary: CANBERRA, Australia - Australia on Monday responded to the Germanwings air disaster by mandating that at least two crew members be present at all times in cockpits of larger domestic and international airliners.

entry.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Never Submitted Sick Note, Airline Says
Germanwings plane crash: Lufthansa to require two crew members in cockpit at all times
entry.summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr says the Lufthansa Group, which includes Germanwings, Austrian Airlines, Swiss Air and Eurowings, will require two crew members to be in the cockpit at all times.

entry.title: French pilots suing over leaks in German jet crash probe
entry.summary: After leaks in the media about the crash, a prosecutor announced that cockpit recordings indicate the co-pilot of the Germanwings A320 jet intentionally flew the plane into a mountain.

entry.title: After Germanwings crash, Denmark wants 2 crew in cockpit
Germanwings co-pilot may have hidden illness
entry.summary:
French investigators, who are in charge of the probe into the plane crash, believe the 27-year-old locked himself inside the cockpit and then intentionally smashed the Germanwings plane into a mountainside on Tuesday during a flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

Germanwings, a low-cost carrier in the Lufthansa Group, said it was setting up a family assistance center in Marseille for relatives of those killed in the crash.

entry.title: German prosecutors: indications Germanwings co-pilot hid illness from employers

entry.summary: "In these dark hours our full attention belongs to the emotional support of the relatives and friends of the victims of Flight 9525," Germanwings CEO Thomas Winkelmann said in a statement.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: captain reportedly tried to force way through cockpit door with axe
entry.summary: Germanwings has confirmed an axe was on board the aircraft.

entry.title: Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash: captain reportedly tried to force way through cockpit door with axe
entry.summary: Berlin: The captain locked out of the cockpit of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps reportedly used an axe to try to force his way back in.

entry.title: Germanwings co-pilot had serious depressive episode: Bild newspaper
Few precedents seen as Germanwings investigation points to deliberate crash
entry.summary: If Andreas Lubitz, Germanwings flight 9525's 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an aeroplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill others in the process.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: how the cockpit door lock works
entry.summary: Evidence from the Germanwings cockpit voice recorder indicates that the co-pilot locked the captain out of the cockpit.

entry.title: Germanwings crash: other pilot-caused tragedies
entry.summary: German police carry boxes out of a house believed to belong to the parents of Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz on Thursday.

entry.title: Germanwings: Andreas Lubitz breakdown six years ago offers clue
Co-pilot who crashed jet was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: Andreas Lubitz never appeared anything but thrilled to have landed a pilot's job with Germanwings, according to those who helped him learn to fly as a teenager in this town in the forested hills of western Germany.

entry.title: German co-pilot crashed plane wilffully: prosecutor
entry.summary: Lufthansa's chief executive said on Thursday he was stunned by the assumption that the co-pilot of a Germanwings jet deliberately crashed it into a mountain in the Alps.

entry.title: German co-pilot crashed plane wilffully: prosecutor
entry.summary: A young German co-pilot locked himself alone in the cockpit of Germanwings flight 9525 and set it on course to crash into an Alpine mountain, killing all 150 people on board including himself, prosecutors said on Thursday.

entry.title: Co-Pilot Was 'Very Happy' With Germanwings Job
entry.summary: After completing his training, Lubitz spent an 11-month waiting period working as a flight attendant before becoming a co-pilot on the Germanwings A320 fleet.

entry.title: Co-pilot was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: Investigators enter the house where the co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings airliner jet is supposed to have lived in an apartment, in Duesseldorf, Germany, Thursday March 26, 2015.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crash: co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was 'happy he had the job' with airline
entry.summary:
Montabaur, Germany: Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz was silent as Germanwings Flight 9525 from Barcelona to Dusseldorf descended for eight minutes before crashing in the French Alps on Tuesday, authorities said.

A sign reading'Crash landing path' stands next to field at the LSC Westerwald flight club in Montabaur where the Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz had been a member.

entry.title: Co-pilot appears to have crashed Germanwings plane deliberately: Prosecutor [Photos] [Video]
entry.summary:
The CEO of Lufthansa, parent company of Germanwings, said its air crew were picked carefully and subjected to psychological vetting.

The co-pilot suspected of deliberately crashing a Germanwings jet into the French Alps on Tuesday has been identified as 28-year-old Andreas Lubitz.

Family members of passengers killed in Germanwings plane crash are escorted by a helper as they arrive at Barcelona's El Prat airport on March 24, 2015.

entry.title: Co-pilot was 'very happy' with Germanwings job
entry.summary: This is an undated image taken from Facebook of Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz in San Francisco California.

entry.title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was 'Very Happy' With Germanwings Job
entry.summary:
On Thursday, French prosecutors said Lubitz, the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525, "intentionally" crashed the jet into the side of a mountain.

After starting his job with Germanwings in September 2013, Lubitz was upbeat when he returned to the LSC Westerwald e.V glider club in the fall to renew his glider pilots' license with 20 or so takeoffs.

Club chairman Klaus Radke said he rejected Marseille prosecutors' conclusion that Lubitz put the Germanwings flight intentionally into a descent and dove it into the French Alps when the pilot had left the cockpit.

entry.title: Co-pilot wanted to ?destroy? Germanwings plane, French prosecutor says
entry.summary: "He was happy he had the job with Germanwings and he was doing well," said a member of the glider club, Peter Ruecker, who watched Lubitz learn to fly.

entry.title: German co-pilot 'appears to have crashed plane deliberately'
entry.summary: The co-pilot of a Germanwings jet that went down in the French Alps, killing 150 people, appears to have crashed the plane deliberately, a Marseille prosecutor said.

entry.title: Searchers recover black box from site as mystery over deadly plane crash in France deepens

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings forced to cancel 7 flights
entry.summary:
Germanwings has had to cancel seven flights out of Dusseldorf because a number of crew members felt they were unfit to fly following news of the accident.

"One must not forget: many of our Germanwings crews have known crew members who were onboard the crashed plane," Spohr said.

entry.title: 16 German high school students among plane crash victims
entry.summary: A Germanwings plane from Barcelona crashed on its way to Duesseldorf over the French alps today, 16 school children and 2 teachers from Haltern are among the victims.

entry.title: The Latest: CEO: Details about plane crash should come soon

French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve says 10 helicopters and a military plane have been mobilized to the site in the French Alps where a Germanwings plane crashed en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

A German official says a high school group returning from an exchange in Spain was on board the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 people onboard.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Lufthansa says Germanwings' lower operating costs helped reduce those losses last year, and that the unit may break even this year.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Lufthansa says better results at Germanwings, along with lower fuel costs, should boost earnings for its airlines division - which also includes Swiss, Eurowings, Lufthansa CityLine, Air Dolomiti and Austrian Airlines - this year.

entry.title: Crash is Germanwings' first fatal accident since 2002 start
entry.summary: Meanwhile, Germanwings' parent company, Lufthansa, has not recorded a passenger fatality since 1993, when another Airbus A320 overshot a runway in Warsaw, Poland, killing one crew and one of 64 passengers.

entry.title: French plane crash is first fatal accident for Germanwings, Lufthansa's low-cost unit
entry.summary: FRANKFURT, Germany - Germanwings, a low-cost unit of Lufthansa, had recorded no accidents involving passenger deaths until one of its planes crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday, killing all 150 on board.

entry.title: Germanwings says had no problem with crashed plane before takeoff
entry.summary: COLOGNE, March 24 (Reuters) - Germanwings said it was unclear what caused its Airbus A320 aircraft to crash in the French Alps on Tuesday but that there had been no problems with the plane before takeoff.

entry.title: 150 dead: Airbus crashes in French Alps
entry.summary: People arrive at a holding area for friends and relatives of passengers on Germanwings flight 4U9525 from Barcelona to Dusseldorf at Dusseldorf International Airport.

entry.title: Plane carrying 150 went into 8-minute descent before crash in Alps
entry.summary: French President Francois Hollande said he believed none of the 148 people on board the Germanwings plane that crashed on Tuesday (March 24) had survived.

entry.title: Germanwings Airbus crashes in French Alps, 150 feared dead
The Latest: French president says no survivors are likely in plane crash in the Alps
entry.summary: The CEO of Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, says he doesn't yet have any information about what happened to its flight from Barcelona to Duesseldorf that French officials say has crashed in the Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings Airbus A320 crashes in French Alps
entry.summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in southern France on Tuesday en route from Barcelona to Duesseldorf, police and aviation officials said.

entry.title: France's Hollande says believes no survivors in plane crash
entry.summary: Airbus confirmed that the plane was 24 years old, having first been delivered to Germanwings parent Lufthansa in 1991.

entry.title: Black box found from Germanwings plane crash in French Alps
Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
entry.summary:
Two Australians are confirmed as being among 150 people killed when an Airbus operated by Lufthansa's Germanwings budget airline crashed in a remote snowy area of the French Alps on Tuesday.

The location of the Germanwings flight 4U9525 crash in the French Alps.

entry.title: Germanwings plane crashes in southern France - police
Black box found at Germanwings plane crash site
entry.summary: The Airbus A320 operated by Germanwings, a budget subsidiary of Lufthansa, was less than an hour from landing in Duesseldorf on a flight from Barcelona when it unexpectedly went into a rapid descent.

entry.title: Plane crashes in French Alps with 150 on board
entry.summary:
The Germanwings logo, normally maroon and yellow, was blacked out on its Twitter feed.

The arrivals board shows flight 4U 9525 without a status at the airport in Duesseldorf, Tuesday, March 24, 2015, after the Germanwings passenger jet crashed in the French Alps as it traveled from Barcelona to Duesseldorf.

Germanwings planes at the airport in Cologne, Germany in 2014.

entry.title: No survivors of Germanwings crash in France, police say
entry.summary: Germanwings said the plane started descending one minute after reaching its cruising height and continued losing altitude for eight minutes.

entry.title: No survivors likely in Airbus A320 crash in French Alps
entry.summary: A Germanwings Airbus A320 with 144 passengers and six crew on board has crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday morning.

entry.title: The Latest: Germanwings says 150 aboard crash plane
